questions.question_text: Users cannot access a webserver and after the traffic is captured, the capture tool shows an ICMP packet that reports "communication administratively prohibited". What is the cause of this webserver access issue?

choices.A: An access list along the path is blocking the traffic.
choices.C: A router along the path is overloaded and thus dropping traffic.
choices.B: Users must authenticate on the webserver to access it.
choices.D: The traffic is not allowed to be translated with NAT and dropped.

discussion.content: Answer A

Answer A
Communication Administratively Prohibited: 
This is generated if a router cannot forward a packet due to administrative filtering. RFC 1812

comments.content:
es corecto en el RFC dice:
 The following additional codes are hereby defined:

 13 = Communication Administratively Prohibited - generated if a
 router cannot forward a packet due to administrative filtering;

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: A
Answer A

"This is generated if a router cannot forward a packet due to administrative filtering."
A is the only filtering option.

A is the right Answer 
Communication Administratively Prohibited.
This is generated if a router cannot forward a packet due to administrative filtering.
B is the right one

comments.content: Server does not reply in ICMP but in the http/https

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: D
NAT is an IETF standard described in RFC 1631: The IP Network Address Translator (NAT). A large number of Cisco and third-party routers and firewalls support NAT. The devices that perform IP address translations are usually situated and route data traffic between the internal network and the outside world or the public Internet.

During the NAT configuration phase, an internal subnet or a set of subnets is defined as being internal, or “inside”; these are usually the private IP subnets used internally in the enterprise. As a second step in the configuration process, single public IP address or an external, or “outside,” pool of IP addresses are defined. With this information, the border device can perform IP address translation between the internal and external worlds.

Selected Answer: A
LB can do the same, configuring a virtual server with the public IP and the port and load balancing the traffic to the backend servers to different ports...the question is not so well written..anyway I would chose A

Selected Answer: A
One option for accessing multiple applications on a single host machine with a single public IP address and port is to use a reverse proxy. A reverse proxy is a type of server that sits in front of one or more backend servers, intercepting traffic from clients and forwarding it to the appropriate backend server.

To use a reverse proxy in this scenario, you would configure the reverse proxy to listen on the public IP address and port, and then configure it to forward traffic to the appropriate local port based on the hostname or URL requested by the client

Selected Answer: A
Reverse Proxy

Selected Answer: A
I'll go with [A] Reverse Proxy

Selected Answer: A
A reverse proxy is exactly used for this.

This is A.
In fact, in my environment I use reverse proxy to channel communications from the public Internet into Intranet.

questions.question_text: Which implementation creates a group of devices on one or more LANs that are configured to communicate as if they were attached to the same wire?
What are two properties of private IP addresses? (Choose two.)

choices.B: They are more secure than public IP addresses.
choices.D: They can be repeated within the same local network.
choices.E: They are controlled globally by an IP address registry.
choices.A: They can be used to access the Internet directly.

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: BC
B = Private addresses cannot be accessed directly from the Internet since they are behind a NAT'd device.
C = Private subnets can be used anywhere privately behind a NAT'd device.

Selected Answer: CD
CD are correct

Selected Answer: CD
Option A is incorrect because private IP addresses, by themselves, cannot be used to access the Internet directly. They need to be translated to a public IP address through a mechanism like Network Address Translation (NAT).

Option B is not entirely accurate. Security is not inherently associated with whether an IP address is private or public. Security measures are implemented independently, and both private and public IP addresses can be used in secure or insecure configurations.

Option E is incorrect because private IP addresses are not controlled globally by an IP address registry. Private IP address ranges are reserved and defined by standards (e.g., RFC 1918) for private network use, but they are not globally managed in the same way as public IP addresses.

Selected Answer: BC
B and C
